data.title: Concerts in Philadelphia for 2024 - Upcoming Concert Calendar
data.meta_description: Some of the biggest names in music are touring through Philly in 2024. View our comprehensive list of upcoming concerts and music fests!
data.text:
Summer is peak concert time in Philadelphia. The sun is shining, temps are rising and open-air venues all over the city welcome top-tier talent to the stage.

The concert calendar is looking especially stacked with names like Missy Elliott, Olivia Rodrigo, P!NK and Bruce Springsteen all slated for the coming months.

Festival season hits its stride with a homegrown event, the Lancaster Avenue Jazz & Arts Festival, which returns to West Philly for the annual celebration of jazz music, plus local vendors and food trucks. Fans of heavier music can head to Underground Arts and Franklin Music Hall for This is Hardcore, a festival dedicated to none other than hardcore.

Even post-summer the concerts show no sign of slowing down. Charli XCX and Troye Sivan, Billie Eilish and Justin Timberlake are coming to town this fall.

Why go home after the encore? Book the Visit Philly Overnight Package and get free hotel parking and choose-your-own-adventure perks, including two tickets to The Franklin Institute, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, or the National Constitution Center and the Museum of the American Revolution. Or get cozy with the new Visit Philly 3-Day Stay hotel package, which includes buy-two-get-a-third-free hotel nights at participating hotels.

Looking for more great concerts? WXPN’s concert calendar is your go-to stop for awesome concerts every day of the week in Greater Philadelphia.

Below, find the top concerts headed to Philly for 2024 — and check back often for updates throughout the year.

Go, get your freak on. The absolutely legendary Missy Elliott is embarking on her first-ever headlining tour after three decades in the biz. Along for the ride are frequent collaborators Ciara, Busta Rhymes and Timbaland. Will we get live versions of Lose Control and 1, 2 Step?

Where: Wells Fargo Center, 3601 S. Broad Street

read more

Now in its fifth year, this traveling emo, pop-punk, and alternative rock festival stops in Philly for a full day of music and summer fun. This year, the festival is headlined by the bands Mayday Parade and The Maine with performances by The Wonder Years, We the Kings, Real Friends, Knuckle Puck, Daisy Grenade, Hot Milk, and Diva Bleach. General admission is standing room only, so be sure to bring a blanket and comfy shoes.

Where: The Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue

read more

The spirit of soul and funk is alive and well in Fairmount Park this August when The Isley Brothers and Gladys Knight come to town. Get down to It’s Your Thing and Pop That Thang by The Isley Brothers and I Heard It Through the Grapevine and Midnight Train to Georgia by Gladys Knight. We know you know every word.

Where: The Dell Music Center, 2400 Strawberry Mansion Drive

read more

Professional dancer turned pop star, Tate McRae hits the sweet spot between sultry and somber, offering a truly contemporary pop sound. Her first global tour takes the TikTok fave to Philly (and beyond, including Sweden, New Zealand and Italy).

Where: The Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue

read more

In case you couldn’t keep up, Future and Metro Boomin released not one, but two collaborative albums this year over the span of three weeks: We Don’t Trust You and We Still Don’t Trust You. Now, the pair welcome you into their space with the We Trust You Tour, a co-headlining evening of trap and hip-hop.

Where: Wells Fargo Center, 3601 S. Broad Street

read more

— Photo courtesy Hootie & the Blowfish

Hootie & the Blowfish took over the soundwaves when their debut album, Cracked Rear View, became one of the 10 best-selling albums in music history. Since then, the group has won Grammys and spawned 17 Billboard-topping singles. The band’s frontman Darius Rucker has even gone on to carve out a place for himself in country music — a departure from Hootie & the Blowfish’s rock origins. The band has come together again for their first major tour since 2019. Get ready for ’90s nostalgia and feel-good tunes like Hold My Hand, Let Her Cry and Only Wanna Be with You.

Where: Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden, NJ

read more

Continuing his Gravel & Gold Tour from last summer, the country musician performs hits from every era of his 20-year career, like What Was I Thinkin’, Drunk On A Plane and Gold.

Where: Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden, NJ

read more

You may have seen him on your TV screens over the last few years, starring in Atlanta and Mr. & Mrs. Smith, but Donald Glover has slipped back into his stage persona, Childish Gambino. He’s touring for the first time since 2019 and since he surprise-released Atavista, the reworked version of his 2020 album 3.15.20.

Where: Wells Fargo Center, 3601 S. Broad Street

read more

— Photo courtesy Avril Lavigne

“Why you have to go and make things so …” You know how the rest goes — and might as well get ready to belt it out with the pop-punk princess herself when she takes the stage in Camden for her Greatest Hits tour. Lavigne promises to perform the most memorable moments from her seven albums, from Let Go to 2022’s Love Sux. Come prepped to sing along to favorites like Sk8er Boi, Complicated, and My Happy Ending.

Where: Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden, NJ

read more

August 30 & 31, 2024

The world was introduced to Usher Raymond as a fresh-faced youngster crooning RnB in the mid-’90s. That talented teenager has grown into a once-in-a-generation performer and indisputable global superstar. Fresh off his explosive Super Bowl halftime performance and a blockbuster, multi-year Las Vegas residency, the hitmaker takes the show on the road. While you can expect some newer music, Usher promises to take audience members on a trip down memory lane with plenty of throwbacks from his extensive catalog from My Boo to OMG.

Where: Wells Fargo Center, 3601 S. Broad Street

read more

The dreamy indie rock band has blown up since its beginnings as 2010s blog favorites. Vocalist Greg Gonzalez’s voice hits that sweet spot between ethereal and hushed, which gives the songs an air of secrecy. They’re now headlining arenas in support of their third album X’s.

Where: Wells Fargo Center, 3601 S. Broad Street

read more

— Photo courtesy The Killers

You know that feeling of jubilation whenever Mr. Brightside comes on in a public place and everyone loses their minds? Expect that — times a million — when The Killers come to Camden. The band will be fresh off of its Las Vegas residency, where they played their debut Hot Fuss in its entirety.

Where: Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden, NJ

read more

September 7 & 8, 2024

One-time Philly resident Katie Crutchfield — aka Waxahatchee — returns to Philly for two nights at the Fillmore to play songs from her Americana-inspired new album Tigers Blood. Also expect deep cuts from earlier in her repertoire, which skews more ’90s alternative.

Where: The Fillmore Philadelphia, 29 E. Allen Street

read more

Sure, he was a member of one of the most popular musical acts ever. But he’s also released 18 albums all on his own. Ringo Starr pulls out all the stops with his All Starr Band featuring Colin Hay (from Men At Work), Steve Lukather (from Toto), Edgar Winter (of the Edgar Winter Group fame), Hamish Stuart (from Average White Band) and Gregg Bissonette (who’s collaborated with David Lee Roth).

Where: The Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue

read more

This double-header goes heavy on vintage sounds. My Morning Jacket bring their brand of psych-infused rock while Nathaniel Rateliff & The Night Sweats lean into honeyed Americana and folk. The pair are the perfect soundtrack to an early fall evening.

Where: The Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue

read more

Over the last two decades, something funny happened: Vampire Weekend turned into a jam band. Live, that is. Hear their expanded and improvised versions of songs like Cape Cod Kwassa Kwassa and cuts from their new album Only God Was Above Us.

Where: The Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue

read more

September 30 & October 1, 2024

One of the most unmistakable voices in music, Sting can belt about Roxanne or draw you in with Every Breath You Take. This tour features Sting on vocals and bass alongside guitarist and longtime collaborator Dominic Miller and drummer Chris Maas (who’s worked with Mumford & Sons and Maggie Rogers). Expect both solo hits and songs from The Police’s catalog.

Where: The Met Philadelphia, 858 N. Broad Street

read more

— Photo by T. Owyoung

2024 Grammy winner for best new artist, Jelly Roll makes his way to Philly this October with his Beautifully Broken tour. The singer-songwriter scored viral success with songs like Dead Man Walking and Son of a Sinner and is known for crisscrossing genres in his music from country to rap and rock with ease. Fans from all backgrounds connect with his honest lyrics and moving life story.

Where: Wells Fargo Center, 3601 S. Broad Street

read more

Want even more great info on upcoming concerts and music festivals in Greater Philadelphia? WXPN, the public radio station of the University of Pennsylvania, curates an excellent calendar of who’s playing where and when. Check it out here.

read more

FAQs About Concerts in Philadelphia

51

What music is Philly most famous for?

It depends who you ask. In the 1960s and ’70s, the city had its own genre, the Sound of Philadelphia (often called TSOP) — a lush and funky form of soul. In the decades since, R&B, hip-hop and indie rock acts have earned acclaim.

Take your pick! You’ll see the next-big things at Union Transfer and Johnny Brenda’s. The Fillmore and Franklin Music Hall are excellent mid-sized venues, and arenas like Wells Fargo Center are where you’ll find the legends.

read more

So much! See world-famous art at our storied museums, shop till you drop and, of course, have a cheesesteak.

read more

Come for Philadelphia. Stay (Over) for Philly.

The only way to fully experience Philly? Stay over.

Book the Visit Philly Overnight Package and get free hotel parking and choose-your-own-adventure perks, including tickets to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, The Franklin Institute, or the National Constitution Center and the Museum of the American Revolution.

Or maybe you’d prefer to buy two Philly hotel nights and get a third night for free? Then book the new Visit Philly 3-Day Stay package.

Which will you choose?

book now
